entry.et: Middle English hindren, from Old English hindrian; akin to Old English hinder behind

def.dt: :to make slow or difficult the progress of :hamper

entry.pt: hinder impede obstruct block mean to interfere with the activity or progress of. hinder stresses causing harmful or annoying delay or interference with progress rain hindered the climb. impede implies making forward progress difficult by clogging, hampering, or fettering tight clothing that impedes movement. obstruct implies interfering with something in motion or in progress by the sometimes intentional placing of obstacles in the way the view was obstructed by billboards. block implies complete obstruction to passage or progress a landslide blocked the road.

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English hinder, adverb
